Flames and smoke rise from Notre Dame Cathedral as it burns in #Paris, April 15, 2019. A catastrophic fire engulfed the upper reaches of the #NotreDame #Cathedral as it was undergoing renovations Monday, threatening one of the greatest architectural treasures of the Western world as tourists and Parisians looked on aghast from the streets below.
#APPhoto Thibault Camus

Protesters clash with police officers during a demonstration against the country’s leadership, in Algiers, #Algeria, April 12, 2019. Heavy police deployment and repeated volleys of water cannon and tear gas didn’t deter masses of Algerians from packing the streets of the capital Friday, insisting that their revolution isn’t over just because the president stepped down. #APPhoto Mosa’ab Elshamy @mosaabelshamy

Flower fields surround Keukenhof spring park in Lisse, near Amsterdam, #Netherlands, April 10, 2019. #APPhoto Peter Dejong @pmsdejong 
For years, the #Dutch agriculture, horticulture and logistics industries have been refined to swiftly deliver their produce to customers in the United Kingdom. A so-called “hard” #Brexit could seriously impact the supply chain with delays expected at British and European ports if Britain leaves the #EU without a deal.

“This is an amazing time to be covering news in Washington, D.C.,” AP Photographer Pablo Martinez Monsivais said. “Just when I thought I’ve seen it all or done it all, photos like this one happen. I’m just lucky to be part of this.” Monsivais took this photo April 10, 2019, of members of the media reflected in the eye of President Donald Trump as he answers questions on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington, before boarding Marine One helicopter. #APPhoto Pablo Martinez Monsivais @pablo3names

On this day in 1945, American soldiers liberated the #Buchenwald concentration camp in #Germany. In this photo, children and other prisoners liberated by the 3rd U.S. Army march from Buchenwald concentration camp near Weimar, Germany, in April 1945. The freed prisoners are walking to an American hospital to receive treatment. The tall youth in the line at left, fourth from the front, is Elie Wiesel. #APPhoto Byron H. Rollins @apphotoarchive

Four #Bedouin women are for the first time leading tours in Egypt’s Sinai Peninsula, breaking new ground in their deeply conservative community, where women almost never work outside the home or interact with outsiders. The women guide groups of female tourists through the stunning mountain landscapes, part of a Bedouin-led project of hiking tours in southern #Sinai aiming to benefit a population that often complains it is left out of major #tourism development. “It is against our culture, but women need jobs,” the 47-year-old Umm Yasser, one of the tour guides, said. “People will make fun of us, but I don’t care. I’m a strong woman.” Photos by Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty #Egypt #APPhoto

Scientists on Wednesday revealed the first image ever made of a black hole, depicting its hot, shadowy edges where light bends around itself in a cosmic funhouse effect. 
Assembling data gathered by eight radio telescopes around the world, astronomers created the picture showing the violent neighborhood around a supermassive black hole, the light-sucking monsters of the universe theorized by Einstein more than a century ago and confirmed by observations for decades. “We have seen what we thought was unseeable. We have seen and taken a picture of a black hole. Here it is,” said Sheperd Doeleman of Harvard. 
Image credit: Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration via Maunakea Observatories

A woman walks past street art by French artist Combo depicting France’s President Emmanuel #Macron and British Prime Minister Theresa May in #Paris, April 9, 2019. #EU leaders will confront May for the second time in three weeks on her exit plans on Wednesday. #APPhoto Thibault Camus

In 1962, a couple is silhouetted against a background of the illuminated Buddhist Pagoda in Ueno Park, #Tokyo. Four 2.5-kilowatt mercury lamps illuminating the five-story ancient building were lit to mark the cherry blossom season. #APPhoto Masao Minagawa 
To see more photos from our photo archive, which dates back to the 19th Century, follow our new @apphotoarchive feed.

Tomorrow, #Rwanda will commemorate the 25th anniversary of when the country descended into violence. In what was the worst genocide in recent history, some 800,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus were massacred by the majority Hutu population over a 100-day period. 
On April 5, 2019, family photographs of some of the infants and children who died hang on display in an exhibition at the Kigali Genocide Memorial center in the capital Kigali, Rwanda. #APPhoto Ben Curtis

A previously little-known Venezuelan congressman, Juan Guaidó, leaped to the front stage of Venezuela’s political conflict by declaring himself interim president in a bid to force the removal of President Nicolas Maduro. The power struggle is playing out amid growing social unrest as millions of Venezuelans have endured nearly a month of rolling blackouts that have crippled water services, public transportation and electronic communication. 
In this April 2, 2019, photo, a child bathes in a brook in Caracas, #Venezuela. #APPhoto Natacha Pisarenko @natachapisarenko

Today in History: Cesar Chavez speaks at a rally in New York City, April 4, 1979. #APPhoto Carlos Rene Perez 
To see more photos from our photo archive, which dates back to the 19th Century, follow our new @apphotoarchive feed.

Women and children wait in a queue for cholera vaccinations, at a camp for displaced survivors of Cyclone Idai in Beira, Mozambique, April 3, 2019. A cholera vaccination campaign is kicking off to reach nearly 900,000 #cyclone survivors in #Mozambique as officials rush to contain an outbreak of the disease. #APPhoto Tsvangirayi Mukwazhi
A woman in wedding attire poses for a photo portrait along a busy street in Xi’an, #China, on March 28, 2019. #APPhoto Mark Schiefelbein

A person wears a mask during a protest against drone warfare at the entrance of the Creech Air Force Base, April 2, 2019, in Indian Springs, Nev. Members of CodePink and other groups have been protesting at the base since Monday, where drone pilots operate. #APPhoto John Locher @locherphoto
The sun rises behind the ‘Eiserner Steg’ (Iron Footbridge) pedestrian bridge in Frankfurt, #Germany, April 2, 2019. #APPhoto Michael Probst @michael_pro

Women comfort each other after learning their relatives were killed in a rainstorm in the Bara district, south of Kathmandu, Nepal, April 1, 2019. Rescuers struggled Monday to reach villages in #Nepal cut off by the rainstorm that killed at least 28 people and injured hundreds more. #APPhoto Niranjan Shrestha
Tourists walk past the #TajMahal, in Agra, India, March 24, 2019. #APPhoto Manish Swarup @manishswarup2050

As Ukraine’s presidential election draws near on Sunday, its ultranationalist groups are becoming increasingly visible, posing a dilemma for the West. Thousands of far-right activists have marched to incumbent President Petro Poroshenko’s administration headquarters, and ultranationalists have also gone to campaign rallies where they fight with police and heckle Poroshenko. The protests reflect the growing presence of far-right groups in #Ukraine and their power in shaping the nation’s political agenda. 
On April 21, 2018, members of the nationalist group Sokil, the youth wing of the Svoboda party, chant slogans and light flares during a concert in Kiev, Ukraine. #APPhoto Felipe Dana @felipedana

A helicopter hovers over Dodger Stadium on Opening Day of the #baseball season on April 10, 1962, as the Los Angeles Dodgers play their first game at the new stadium against the Cincinnati Reds in Los Angeles, Calif. The Dodgers lost to the Reds 6-3. 
Today, the Dodgers take on the Arizona Diamondbacks at the same stadium for #OpeningDay. To see more photos from our archive, follow our new @apphotoarchive feed. #APPhoto #APPhotoArchive

Opening Day for #baseball is here and with it comes the promise of a new season, footlong hot dogs, ice-cold drinks and scenes of beautifully manicured ballpark grass. This offseason another type of green was growing: Massive contracts. 
Bryce Harper, from left, Mike Trout and Manny Machado all signed three of the largest contracts in MLB history this offseason. Machado was first, signing a $300 million deal with San Diego for 10 years. Next came Harper, who signed for 13 years and $330 million to play in Philadelphia. Trout, a two-time MVP considered the game’s best all-around player, followed with a $426.5 million, 12-year contract. 
#APIllustration Peter Hamlin @peterhamlinillustrates

A worker prepares flags as part of campaign material for Indian political parties ahead of elections in Ahmadabad, #India, March 25, 2019. India’s national election will be held in seven phases between April 11 and May 19, 2019. #APPhoto Ajit Solanki @ajitsolankiap

Fans take pictures of the ‘KAWS:HOLIDAY’ ‘Companion’, at the waterfront of the Victoria Harbour after the opening ceremony for its exhibition in #HongKong, March 22, 2019. The 37-meter long ‘KAWS:HOLIDAY’ ‘Companion’, is an inflatable sculpture created by U.S. artist and designer Brian Donnelly, known professionally as Kaws. #APPhoto Kin Cheung

A girl gestures with her hands as colored water is splashed on her during celebrations marking #Holi festival in Allahabad, India, on March 21, 2019. Holi, the festival of colors, also marks the advent of spring. #APPhoto Rajesh Kumar Singh

Children launch kites during Nowruz celebration as the sun sets in Baghdad, Iraq, March 21, 2019. Nowruz, the Farsi-language word for “new year”, is an ancient Persian festival, celebrated on the first day of spring in countries including Iraq, Turkey, Afghanistan and Iran. The festival is a symbolic opportunity to purify the soul for the new year and symbolizes revival and is marked by spring cleaning, buying new clothes and planting trees. March 21, the first day of spring, marks Nowruz. #APPhoto Hadi Mizban

Worn down by three years of indecision in London, #EU leaders on Thursday grudgingly offered the #UK more time for #Brexit, delaying by several weeks the threat of a chaotic exit from the bloc. Here, activists pose with their faces painted in colors of the EU and Union Jack flags outside EU headquarters during an EU summit in #Brussels, March 21, 2019. #APPhoto Frank Augstein

#OTD in 1965, Martin Luther King, Jr. and a group of civil rights demonstrators head for Montgomery, Ala., from #Selma, during a five day, 50-mile walk to protest voting laws. Soldiers were called out by President Johnson to protect the marchers. 
To see more photos from our archive, follow our new @apphotoarchive feed.

A child wearing a costume runs up the steps during Purim celebrations at the Coral Temple in Bucharest, Romania, March 20, 2019. Children put on costumes and attended a Purim service to celebrate the Jews’ salvation from genocide in ancient Persia, as recounted in the Book of Esther. #APPhoto Vadim Ghirda @vadimghirda
Waves crash against the Malecon sea wall as a taxi drives past in Havana, Cuba, March 19, 2019. #APPhoto Ramon Espinosa @aprespinosa

Orangutan populations in Indonesia’s Borneo and Sumatra island are facing severe threats from habitat loss, illegal logging, fires and poaching. Conservationists predicted that without immediate action, orangutans are likely to be the first great ape to become extinct in the wild. Here, a veterinarian and a volunteer of Sumatra Orangutan Conservation Program (SOCP) tend to a 3-month-old baby orangutan named ‘Brenda’ that was evacuated from a village with a broken arm, before surgery at SOCP facility in Sibolangit, Indonesia on March 17, 2019. 
#APPhoto Binsar Bakkara @binsarbakkara

Springtime in northern Greece is ushered with loud and colorful festivals, many hailing from centuries-old traditions, later tied to the religious calendar. In villages across the region, there are drums, ear-piercing pipe music, customs passed on from grandparents and the centerpiece of many of the region’s celebrations: Masks. AP photographer @petrosgiannakouris captured a series of these elaborate outfits. #APPhotos

New York’s $25 billion Hudson Yards development opened to the public today. When fully complete, the 28-acre site will include the sculpture seen here named the Vessel, 16 towers of homes and offices, a hotel, a school, the highest outdoor observation deck in the Western Hemisphere, a performing arts center and a shopping mall. #APPhoto Mark Lennihan

AP is aboard the Ocean Zephyr with the British-led Nekton Mission for a seven-week expedition. Scientists aim to understand what lies in uncharted Indian Ocean waters and map the seabed. Using crewed submersibles, they’re able to explore depths of up to 300 meters (about 980 feet). The AP this week broadcast the world's first multi-camera live signal in full broadcast quality from a manned submersibles. Using optical video transmission techniques, the pictures were transmitted through the waves using the blue region of the electromagnetic spectrum. 
Here, the manned submersible surfaces after dark after a mission to recover a stranded ROV (Remotely Operated Vehicle), in the Indian Ocean near the Seychelles, March 13, 2019. #APPhoto David Keyton @davidkeyton

On this day, 140 years ago, Nobel Prize-winning physicist Albert Einstein was born. Einstein was born in Ulm, Germany on March 14, 1879. Encouraged by his father, who was an electrical engineer, Einstein studied at the Zurich Polytechnic Institute until the age of 21, shortly afterwards starting work at the Swiss Patent Office. Although famous for his papers on special and general relativity, he won the 1921 Nobel Prize for physics for his work on the photoelectric effect. Einstein died on April 18, 1955 without completing his Grand Unified Theory of the fundamental forces.

This portrait of Albert Einstein was taken in Princeton, New Jersey in June, 1954. To see more photos from our archive, follow our new @apphotoarchive feed. #APPhoto #APPhotoArchive

A child is rescued from the rubble of a collapsed building in Lagos, Nigeria, March 13, 2019. #APPhoto Sunday Alamba @salambaphoto 
Rescue efforts are underway in Nigeria after a three-story school building collapsed while classes were in session, with some scores of children thought to be inside at the time.

A worker attaches a name tag of a Buddhist who made a donation to a lantern for the upcoming celebration of Buddha’s birthday on May 12 at the Jogye temple in Seoul, South Korea, March 13, 2019. Similar lanterns will be displayed in all Buddhist temples around South Korea for the public viewing. #APPhoto Ahn Young-joon
A man is silhouetted at dusk as he fishes on a dock at Shawnee Mission Park, in Lenexa, Kan., March 11, 2019. #APPhoto Charlie Riedel @charlie_riedel_pix
Smoke rises as U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) battle Islamic State militants remaining in a pocket of Baghouz, Syria, March 11, 2019. #APPhoto Maya Alleruzzo @mayaalleruzzo

Workers gather at the scene of an Ethiopian Airlines flight crash in Hejere near Bishoftu, Ethiopia on March 11, 2019. #APPhoto Mulugeta Ayene @mulugetaayene
Authorities in Ethiopia, China and Indonesia have grounded all Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft following the crash of an Ethiopian Airlines jetliner that killed 157 people.

Farmaan, 7, poses for a photograph near his home, a wooden fruit vendor’s cart, in New Delhi, India on Jan. 18, 2019. #APPhoto Altaf Qadri @altafqadri 
For this desperately poor Indian family, barely educated and living on the fringes of New Delhi life, hope can be found in Farmaan with huge eyes and scraggly hair. Simply by staying in school he has become the focus of the family’s dreams.

A man works on a tomato poster as part of an advertisement, near Almería city, in the autonomous community of Andalusia, Spain on March 1, 2019. #APPhoto Emilio Morenatti @emilio_morenatti 
Britain’s impending departure from the European Union could punch a multi-million-euro hole in the fruit and vegetable business here. By throwing up borders with the EU, Brexit could bring long waits at customs posts for trucks with wilting loads.

Liquid iron in a steel pouring ladle wait for further processing, during a guided media tour at the steel producer Salzgitter AG in Salzgitter, Germany, on March 5, 2019. #APPhoto Markus Schreiber @markus__schreiber

Granadas Baker retrieves personal items from his home after a tornado caused extensive damage to a neighborhood a day earlier in Beauregard, Ala., March 4, 2019. #AP Photo David Goldman @apdavidgoldman 
The more than 20 people killed in the nation's deadliest tornado in nearly six years came into focus Tuesday with the release of their names by coroner. The youngest victim was 6, the oldest 89. One extended family lost seven members.
A performer from the Paraiso do Tuiuti samba school parades during Carnival celebrations at the Sambadrome in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, March 5, 2019. #APPhoto Leo Correa @leocorrea21

Thousands of people are flocking to North Woodstock, N.H., to visit Ice Castles, a winter wonderland constructed from ice. #APPhotos Robert F. Bukaty

It starts small in December, when a team sets up icicle farms: metal racks that are sprayed with water to allow icicles to grow on them overnight. The team then harvests the icicles and continually sprays them with water. The site features a collection of ice tunnels, caverns and a 97-foot (30-meter) ice slide. The winter wonderland is one of six in North America.
A man rides a one-wheel electric skateboard past the European Council headquarters in Brussels, Feb. 28, 2019. #APPhoto Francisco Seco @francisco_seco

President Donald Trump speaks as Secretary of State Mike Pompeo looks on during a news conference after a summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, Feb. 28, 2019, in Hanoi. #APPhoto Evan Vucci @evanvucci 
Talks between Trump and Kim collapsed Thursday after the two sides failed to bridge a standoff over U.S. sanctions, a dispiriting end to high-stakes meetings meant to disarm a global nuclear threat. Trump blamed the breakdown on North Korea’s insistence that all the punishing sanctions the U.S. has imposed on Pyongyang be lifted without the North committing to eliminate its nuclear arsenal.

Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump’s former personal lawyer, is sworn in to testify before the House Oversight and Reform Committee on Capitol Hill in Washington, Feb. 27, 2019. #APPhoto J. Scott Applewhite 
Cohen is testifying under oath before the committee — and has said that Trump instructed him to pay off women who said they’d had affairs with the president. Trump has denied the claims.

U.S.-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) fighters walk in a building as the fight against Islamic State militants continue in the village of Baghouz, Syria, Feb. 16, 2019. #APPhoto Felipe Dana @felipedana 
Dozens of trucks arrived Tuesday at the outskirts of a besieged enclave held by the Islamic State group in eastern Syria, signaling renewed efforts to evacuate hundreds of civilians trapped in the militants’ last patch of territory along the Euphrates River. A spokesman for the U.S.-backed Syrian militia that is spearheading the fight against IS said a military operation aimed at ousting the extremists from the enclave will begin if they don’t surrender.

In the 100 days since a wildfire nearly burned the town of Paradise, Calif., off the map, the long recovery is just starting. Artist Shane Grammer, who painted this mural photographed on Feb. 8, 2019, says he paints murals throughout the fire-ravaged town to convey hope in the midst of destruction. #APPhoto Noah Berger @noah3929

A year ago today, Mechelle Boyle, right, embraced Cathi Rush in this image that became emblematic of the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting in Parkland, Fla., on Feb. 14, 2018.

At the time of this picture, Rush was desperately trying to get in touch with her son Brandon, who had texted that he was hiding under a table. However, the bond depicted in the photograph didn’t last long. The two women soon found themselves at odds over gun control.

Rush ultimately learned that her son Brandon was safe. #APPhoto Joel Auerbach

A wire fox from Brazil who’s won big in Europe became America’s top dog Tuesday night, beating out a crowd-pleasing longhaired dachshund and popular Sussex spaniel.

There were some boos — along with modest cheers — at Madison Square Garden when judge Peter Green pointed at the 7-year-old King.

Wire fox terriers have won 15 times at the nation’s most prestigious dog show, far more than any other breed (Scottish terriers are second, with eight). #APPhoto Frank Franklin II

President Donald Trump waves as he arrives to board Air Force One at Andrews Air Force Base in Md., Feb. 11, 2019. Trump is heading to El Paso, Texas, to try and turn the debate over a wall at the U.S.-Mexico border back to his political advantage as his signature pledge to American voters threatens to become a model of unfulfilled promises. #APPhoto Susan Walsh

Firefighters battle flames in San Francisco, Feb. 6, 2019. A gas explosion shot flames high into the air Wednesday, burning multiple buildings as utility crews scrambled to shut off the flow of gas. #APPhoto Jeff Chiu @jchiu34

Democratic members of Congress, including Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., center, pose for a photo before President Donald Trump delivers his State of the Union address to a joint session of Congress on Capitol Hill in Washington, Feb. 5, 2019. #APPhoto J. Scott Applewhite

Wearing the color of the suffragists, the Democratic women of the House put on a display of solidarity during the State of the Union address Tuesday. They paid tribute to the women who came before them and gave a nod to their own achievement, as more women than ever are now representatives in the House.

A Venezuelan woman returns to her country after buying groceries in La Parada, on the outskirts of Cucuta, Colombia, on the border with Venezuela, Feb. 4, 2019. #APPhoto Fernando Vergara 
Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaido is moving ahead with plans to try to bring in humanitarian aid through Cucuta, where the U.S. government will transport and store food and medical supplies destined for Venezuela. The Venezuelan opposition has said that once the aid is stockpiled in Cucuta, it will try to move it into Venezuela, defying Nicolas Maduro’s government, which has refused offers of aid from the U.S. and other Western nations.

New England Patriots’ Tom Brady (12) embraces teammate Julian Edelman (11) after the NFL Super Bowl 53 football game against the Los Angeles Rams, Sunday, Feb. 3, 2019, in Atlanta. The Patriots won 13-3. Brady captured his sixth NFL title. #APPhoto Morry Gash @morryg

A portrait of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini is displayed at his grave, just outside of Tehran, Iran. #APPhoto Ebrahim Noroozi @ebrahimnoroozi 
Khomeini was the face of Iran’s Islamic Revolution. His image is on bank notes and in textbooks in Iran, often as a black-and-white embodiment of the 1979 Islamic Revolution that swept aside the country’s shah and forever changed the nation.

Chinese women pose for a selfie near a tree decorated with red lanterns ahead of the Chinese Lunar New Year at Ditan Park in Beijing, Jan. 30, 2019. Chinese will celebrate Lunar New Year on Feb. 5, which marks the Year of the Pig on the Chinese zodiac. #APPhoto Andy Wong @andywong0619

Scenes from a deadly arctic deep freeze that enveloped the Midwest with record-breaking temperatures triggering widespread closures of schools and businesses, and the canceling of more than 1,600 flights from Chicago’s airports. #APPhotos David Joles @startribune, Kiichiro Sato @apksato, Orlin Wagner and Rich Hein @chicagosuntimes 
The bitter cold is the result of a split in the polar vortex that allowed temperatures to drop much farther south than normal. That meant temperatures in parts of the Midwest were lower Wednesday than in parts of Antarctica.

Water buffaloes bathe in a hot spring near the village of Budakli, in the mountainous Bitlis province of eastern Turkey on Jan. 24, 2019. #APPhoto Emrah Gurel @gurel_emrah 
Residents of the village with some 60 homes walk hundreds of buffaloes up snow-covered roads to the geothermal springs in the winter. Villagers say the hot springs heal buffaloes' wounds, alleviate discomfort in their breasts and make quality milk. The village's main source of income is cheese, butter and milk from the buffaloes.

Hand prints in mud and fake blood are placed on a glass window during a protest at the door of the Brazilian mining company Vale, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Jan. 28, 2019. There is mounting anger directed at Vale amid questions about the area’s largest employer following an apparent lack of a warning siren ahead of Friday’s collapse at one of its dams. #APPhoto Silvia Izquierdo

A man walks through the gate of the Sachsenhausen Nazi death camp with the phrase ‘Arbeit macht frei’ (work sets you free) at the International Holocaust Remembrance Day in Oranienburg, north of Berlin, Germany, Jan. 27, 2019. The International Holocaust Remembrance Day marks the liberation of the Auschwitz Nazi death camp on Jan. 27, 1945. #APPhoto Markus Schreiber @markus__schreiber

Flanked by Panama’s President Juan Carlos Varela, right, and first lady Lorena Castillo, Pope Francis arrives at the foreign ministry headquarters Palacio Bolivar, in Panama City, Jan. 24, 2019. Pope Francis is in Panama Jan. 23-27 for World Youth Day events. #APPhoto Alessandra Tarantino @alexiati00
A musher competes with his dogs during the Sedivackuv Long dog sled race near the village of Destne v Orlicky Horach, Czech Republic, Jan. 25, 2019. #APPhoto Petr David Josek @joskinenn

The roof of Rod Laver Arena is closed during the women’s semifinal between Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic and United States’ Danielle Collins due to extreme heat at the Australian Open tennis championships in Melbourne, Australia, Jan. 24, 2019. #APPhoto Andy Brownbill @andybrownbill

Anti-government protesters cheer as Juan Guaido, head of Venezuela’s opposition-run congress, declares himself interim president of the South American country until a new election can be called, at a rally demanding the resignation of President Nicolas Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, Jan. 23, 2019. #APPhoto Boris Vergara @bvphotographer

After hours of research to find a location with ideal weather conditions, AP photographer @petrosgiannakouris captured the first full moon of the year, Jan. 21, 2019, during a total Lunar eclipse. Here it sets over the Larissa medieval castle of Argos, Greece, which is one of the oldest cities in the world. #APPhoto Petros Giannakouris

German Chancellor Angela Merkel looks at French President Emmanuel Macron after the signing of a new Germany-France friendship treaty at the historic Town Hall in Aachen, Germany, Jan. 22, 2019. The new Treaty of Aachen is the succession of the 1963 Elysee Treaty signed by West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the then French President Charles de Gaulle. #APPhoto Martin Meissner
Competitors ride their motorbike across the dunes during stage nine of the Dakar Rally in Pisco, Peru, Jan. 16, 2019. #APPhoto Ricardo Mazalan
Snow is kicked up by the prop wash as Marine One carrying President Donald Trump departs the South Lawn of the White House, Jan. 14, 2019, in Washington. #APPhoto Evan Vucci @evanvucci

In this photograph taken with a slow shutter speed, on Jan. 6, 2019, a man warms up his horse before an Epiphany celebration horse race in Pietrosani, Romania. Epiphany celebrations bring together hundreds of people in the Romanian village of Pietrosani for a day out in freezing temperatures that culminates in a bareback horse race across muddy, frozen or snowy fields. #APPhoto Vadim Ghirda @vadimghirda
A girl plays beneath an Argentine flag as demonstrators protest against the increase in public service fees, in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Jan. 10, 2019. #APPhoto Natacha Pisarenko @natachapisarenko

Workers replace sections of the border wall, left, with new sections, right, Jan. 8, 2019, in Tijuana, Mexico. President Donald Trump is taking the shutdown battle to the U.S.-Mexico border today, seeking to bolster his case for the border wall after negotiations with Democrats blew up over his funding demands. #APPhoto Gregory Bull @gregorybull

Members of the Congolese opposition coalition Lamuka, led by presidential candidate Martin Faluyu, have a conversation while waiting for a statement to be issued on the timing of the release of the presidential election results in Kinshasa, Congo, Jan. 5, 2019. Congo faces what could be its first democratic, peaceful transfer of power since independence from Belgium in 1960, but election observers and the opposition have raised numerous concerns about voting irregularities as the country chooses a successor to longtime President Joseph Kabila.  Congo’s government Sunday postponed the release of the results of last weekend’s presidential election, fueling suspicions President Joseph Kabila’s ruling party is maneuvering to cling to power. No new date for announcing the winner of the Dec. 30 election was given. #APPhoto Jerome Delay @jeromedelay

Strangers sit together as they wait in the Hoyt-Schermerhorn subway station made famous in several movies as well as Michael Jackson’s music video “Bad” on Aug. 27, 2018, in the Brooklyn borough of New York. #APPhoto Wong Maye-E @w0ngmayee 
Hi @apnews followers. My name is Wong Maye-E (@w0ngmayee). I am an Associated Press photojournalist. Until last year, I spent my entire life living in Asia and photographing it. I’ve gone elsewhere and done assignments – everywhere from North Korea to Russia to Brazil. But I never lived anywhere else until now. And now, the place where I live is one of the most famous in the world. How on Earth would I photograph that? With all the elaborate camera equipment I use in my job, it’s my phone – the camera that’s always with me – that I often find shows me the world around me in the most intimate way. After six months here, New York is not quite mine yet, but here – for now – is my New York. 
I have been taking over the @apnews Instagram feed for the past few days. This is my final post. Thank you for following me!

Hi @apnews followers. My name is Wong Maye-E (@w0ngmayee). I am an Associated Press photojournalist and I will be taking over the @apnews instagram feed for the next few days. Until last year, I spent my entire life living in Asia and photographing it. 
I’ve gone elsewhere and done assignments – everywhere from North Korea to Russia to Brazil. But I never lived anywhere else until now. And now, the place where I live is one of the most famous in the world. How on Earth would I photograph that? With all the elaborate camera equipment I use in my job, it’s my phone – the camera that’s always with me – that I often find shows me the world around me in the most intimate way. After six months here, New York is not quite mine yet, but here – for now – is my New York.

Hi @apnews followers. My name is Wong Maye-E (@w0ngmayee ). I am an Associated Press photojournalist and I will be taking over the @apnews Instagram feed for the next few days. Until last year, I spent my entire life living in Asia and photographing it. 
I’ve gone elsewhere and done assignments – everywhere from North Korea to Russia to Brazil. But I never lived anywhere else until now. And now, the place where I live is one of the most famous in the world. How on Earth would I photograph that? With all the elaborate camera equipment I use in my job, it’s my phone – the camera that’s always with me – that I often find shows me the world around me in the most intimate way. After six months here, New York is not quite mine yet, but here – for now – is my New York.  The photos that you see here were captured on my iPhone over the past six months.

A migrant jumps the border fence to get into the U.S. side to San Diego, Calif., from Tijuana, Mexico, Jan. 1, 2019. Discouraged by the long wait to apply for asylum through official ports of entry, many migrants from recent caravans are choosing to cross the U.S. border wall and hand themselves in to border patrol agents. #APPhoto Daniel Ochoa de Olza @danielochoadeolza
Lorraine Bates, center, pours champagne into her slipper for Robert Tuton as they celebrate on New Year’s Eve at the Hotel Lexington’s Hawaiian room in New York, Dec. 31, 1939. #APPhoto Tom Sande

For many people in the region, diving is the only way to fight their poverty, no matter the risks. A diver, who makes seven lempiras or about 28 U.S. cents per sea cucumber, will catch anywhere between 10 and 30 in a day.

President Donald Trump kisses first lady Melania Trump during a hanger rally on a surprise trip to Al Asad Air Base, Iraq, Dec. 26, 2018. President Trump says he has ‘no plans at all’ to remove U.S. troops from the country. #APPhoto Andrew Harnik @andyharnik

An American flag is raised at a “topping-out” ceremony, the raising of an American flag on the topmost girder, to mark the completion of the steelwork on the 15-story new Associated Press building at Rockefeller Center, New York, June 16, 1938. Brady

Young Boca Juniors soccer fans react to losing to River Plate as they watch on TV the Copa Libertadores final in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Dec. 9, 2018. River Plate won 3-1. Pakistani nomad women carry water to their houses in a hazy evening on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, Dec. 4, 2018. A migrant woman helps carry a handmade U.S. flag up the riverbank at the Mexico-U.S. border after getting past Mexican police at the Chaparral border crossing in Tijuana, Mexico, Nov. 25, 2018, as a group of migrants tries to reach the U.S. #APPhoto Ramon Espinosa @aprespinosa
Mexico pledged to shore up security near its border with the United States and local authorities said that more than 35 migrants were arrested Sunday after a peaceful march devolved into chaos when U.S. agents fired tear gas into Mexico to stop some migrants who tried to breach the border.

Children walk through the Cathedral of Light as part of the illuminated trail through Kew Gardens magnificent after-dark landscape, lit up by over one million twinkling lights in London, Nov. 21, 2018. #APPhoto Frank Augstein

Young participants of the "Temper of will" summer camp, organized by Svoboda party, sit inside a tent with their AK-47 rifles as they receive instructions during a tactical exercise, July 28, 2018, in a village near Ternopil, Ukraine. #APPhoto Felipe Dana @felipedana 
An Associated Press visit to a summer camp created by a Ukrainian nationalist group finds children as young as 8 being taught to use assault rifles to kill Russians and their sympathizers. At the same time, they are being inculcated with nationalist ideology, including derision of LGBT rights, which lecturers denounce as a sign of Western decadence. The nationalists have built a network of such camps, some of them partially financed by the government.

Terrill @mjterrill1

Ron Helus went by Nov. 8, 2018, in Newbury Park, Calif. Helus was fatally shot while responding to a mass shooting at a country music bar in Southern California. #APPhoto Marcio Jose Sanchez
A slum colony is decorated with lanterns and lights as they celebrate the Hindu festival Diwali in Mumbai, India, Nov. 6, 2018. #APPhoto Rafiq Maqbool

Ethiopian Jews pray during 'Sigd,' a holiday primarily celebrated by the Jewish community from Ethiopia, in Jerusalem, Nov. 7, 2018. Sigd symbolizes the acceptance of the Torah, the Jewish holy scripture, and became an Israeli national holiday in 2008. #APPhoto Ariel Schalit @arielschalitphotos

Hello @apnews followers! This is Associated Press photojournalist Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty and visual journalist Bram Janssen @bram_anna. This is the last post in our @apnews @instagram feed takeover focused on our investigation into global migration, which has soared to record highs in recent years. 
In this April 16, 2018 photo, ship and boat wrecks that once carried African migrants stand along the shoreline of Monastir, Tunisia. Often the tides of the Mediterranean bring the bodies of migrants as well and their belongings, washing them ashore on the North African beaches they had hoped would be their last stop before Europe. 
#APPhoto @narimanelmofty

Hello @apnews followers! This is Associated Press photojournalist Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty  and visual journalist Bram Janssen @bram_anna. We are taking over the @apnews @instagram feed today as part of an investigation into global migration that has soared to record highs, with more than 258 million international migrants in 2017. 
The Mediterranean has in recent years been robbing Tunisia of its young, who abandon their homeland in hopes of a better life in Europe. In this April 14, 2018 photo, Ahmed Ayouby, who wants to leave Tunisia, smokes a cigarette at the beach in Ras Jebel, Tunisia, where migrants leave for Italy. 
#APPhoto @narimanelmofty

Hello @apnews followers! This is Associated Press visual journalist Bram Janssen @bram_anna and photojournalist Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty. We are taking over the @apnews @instagram feed for the next two days as part of an investigation into global migration that has soared to record highs. 
In this Jan. 24, 2018 photo, a pathologist transfers a body of an unidentified male after finishing a forensic examination in the Johannesburg mortuary. The mortuary is the busiest in the country. Crime rates and traffic accidents are steep and the mortuary's freezer is almost always full. 
Millions of migrants have slipped in through South Africa’s porous borders for years without documentation. They live a life of anonymity. And when they die, they remain unidentified. Those bodies are eventually buried in “pauper” graves. 
A pilot project has been started to take detailed photos, fingerprints, dental information and DNA samples of unidentified bodies. That information goes to a database where, in theory, the bodies can be traced. Sometimes they have a match. Mortuary workers see those instances as small victories. 
#APPhoto @bram_anna

#APPhoto @narimanelmofty

Hello @apnews followers! This is Associated Press visual journalist Bram Janssen @bram_anna and photojournalist Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty. We are taking over the @apnews @instagram feed together for the next two days as part of an investigation into global migration that has soared to record highs. 
This photo shows Kholakele, her husband Arnold and their children. They left their home in Zimbabwe three years ago, hoping to find work in South Africa. Arnold (left) is an artist, crafting little sculptures from wires that he tries to sell on Johannesburg’s streets. Kholakele, carrying their 6-month-old baby, looks after the children. 
Kholakele says she heard many stories about missing migrants from friends and relatives. Afraid that one day they will end up as anonymous bodies in the city, where crime rates and traffic accidents are steep, they barely let their children out of sight. They fear for their five children. “If one of them stays away for longer than 10 minutes, we phone them,” Kholakele says. 
Millions of migrants have slipped in through South Africa’s porous borders for years without documentation. They live a life of anonymity. And when they die, they remain unidentified. Those bodies are eventually buried in “pauper” graves. 
#APPhoto @bram_anna

Hello @apnews followers! This is Associated Press photojournalist Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty and visual journalist Bram Janssen @bram_anna. 
We are taking over the @apnews @instagram feed together for the next few days as part of an investigation into global migration that has soared to record highs, with more than 258 million international migrants in 2017. Migrants who go missing are a daily reproach to political failure, so there is rarely an official count of the departed, the dead or the disappeared. 
In this April 11, 2018, photo, Mounira Abu Shakra weeps thinking of her son Amin Bin Hussein who went missing migrating to Italy. 11 young Tunisians disappeared off the coast in 2011 and were never counted by their government. They left behind mothers, who on a clear day can see the island where the boat crashed against the rocks and sank. #APPhoto @narimanelmofty

Hello @apnews followers! This is Associated Press photojournalist Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty and visual journalist Bram Janssen @bram_anna. We are taking over the @apnews @instagram feed together for three days as part of an investigation into global migration that has soared to record highs, with more than 258 million international migrants in 2017. 
Migrants who go missing are a daily reproach to political failure, so there is rarely an official count of the departed, the dead or the disappeared. 
Often the tides of the Mediterranean Sea bring ashore the bodies and belongings of others who attempted a similar migration, those from distant countries who had hoped the beaches of North Africa would be their last stop before Europe. 
This photo shows the “Cemetery of the Unknown,” which holds 67 bodies of migrants who were found dead on shores, at the southern port town of Zarzis, Tunisia, April 15, 2018. #APPhoto @narimanelmofty

This is Associated Press visual journalist Bram Janssen @bram_anna and photojournalist Nariman El-Mofty @narimanelmofty. 
We will be taking over the @apnews @instagram feed together for three days.  As people worldwide flee war, hunger and a lack of jobs, global migration has soared to record highs. Far less visible, however, has been its toll: The tens of thousands of people who die or simply disappear during their journeys, never to be seen again. 
With a prosperous economy and stable government, South Africa draws more migrants than any other country in Africa. 
Crime rates and traffic accidents in Johannesburg are steep, which causes a continuous flow of dead bodies. The Johannesburg mortuary receives more than 3,000 bodies per year. Ten percent of those remain unidentified. 
This photo shows the skull of an adult male, found in 2017 in Johannesburg, is laid out on a table inside the mortuary. Once a demographic profile is estimated for the skeletons and skulls, it will go to the victim identification center in the South African police department to create a facial reconstruction. 
#APPhoto @bram_anna
A man walks by an oak tree displaying fall colors on the grounds of the National World War I Museum, Oct. 29, 2018, in Kansas City, Mo. #APPhoto Charlie Riedel @charlie_riedel_pix

Students from the Yeshiva School in the Squirrel Hill neighborhood of Pittsburgh, pay their respects as the funeral procession for Dr. Jerry Rabinowitz passes their school en route to Homewood Cemetery following a funeral service at the Jewish Community Center, Oct. 30, 2018. Pittsburgh's Jewish community has started to bury its dead in the wake of the deadliest anti-Semitic attack in American history. #APPhoto Gene J. Puskar

Hospital beds sit at the Masaidiano Health Center in Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of the Congo on Aug. 14, 2018. #APPhoto Jerome Delay @jeromedelay 
An Associated Press investigation found that of more than 20 hospitals and clinics visited in Lubumbashi, all but one detain patients, an illegal practice according to the Congolese penal code. Many hospitals lack running water and regular electricity and bed shortages are often so severe that two patients must squeeze onto a single mattress.

Alice Kabuya, 20, right, looks at a clinic employee at the Masaidizi Health Center in Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of the Congo on Aug. 14, 2018. #APPhoto Jerome Delay @jeromedelay 
Kabuya gave birth to her daughter at the facility but is unable to pay the $150 medical bill. She said the clinic's doors were locked every afternoon and that she could not walk more than about 10 feet outside before being reprimanded by nurses.

Gabriel Mutamba lies on his hospital bed at the Katuba Reference Hospital in Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of the Congo on Aug. 13, 2018. #APPhoto Jerome Delay  @jeromedelay 
Mutamba, in his 80s, was first brought to the hospital in 2017 by a church group that found him with a broken leg. Though doctors fixed his leg in surgery, he subsequently developed other problems. While he's now stable enough to leave, he's also racked up a substantial bill and hospital officials have so far refused to discharge him. One of the hospital's cleaning women took pity on Mutamba and occasionally brings him food but otherwise, he has few visitors and no family offering to help clear his bill.

Members of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a hard-line Hindu group that created the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party as its political arm, attend Vijay Dashmi festival celebrations in Allahabad, India on Oct. 19, 2018. Vijayadashami, also known as Dussehra, commemorates the victory of the Hindu god Rama over demon god Ravana. The festivity is marked with the burning of effigies of Ravana, signifying the victory of good over evil. #APPhoto Rajesh Kumar Singh

A Turkish forensic officer arrives at the Saudi consulate to conduct a new search over the disappearance of Saudi writer Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul on Oct. 18, 2018. Khashoggi, vanished after he walked into the consulate on Oct. 2, leading worldwide speculation over his disappearance. #APPhoto Emrah Gurel @gurel_emrah
A boy plays in the bounce house at a pumpkin patch Oct. 9, 2018, in Seal Beach, Calif. #APPhoto Jae Hong @jaechongpix

Honduran migrants sleep in an improvised shelter in Esquipulas, Guatemala, Oct. 15, 2018. Despite having walked all day Monday with swollen, blistered and aching feet, the group was up shortly after sunrise as it resumed their northward trek through Guatemala with hopes of reaching the U.S. border. #APPhoto Moises Castillo @mfca1975
Male swimmers start the swim race at the Ironman World Championship Triathlon, Oct. 13, 2018, in Kailua Kona, Hawaii. #APPhoto Marco Garcia @marcogarciaphotography

A craftsman holds a dagger or ‘Jambiyya’ in Yemeni Arabic, made out of remains of missiles, in Hajjah, Yemen on Oct. 6, 2018. #APPhoto Hammadi Issa
Missiles raining on Yemen from the jets of the Saudi-led coalition fighting Houthi rebels are killing thousands of civilians and militiamen alike, but amid crashing economy, some Yemenis see the bright side of it: they make daggers out of the fragments of the missiles for ordinary men traditionally worn for prestige and a show of courage.

Members of “Castellers de Sants” complete their human tower during the 27th Human Tower Competition in Tarragona, Spain, on Oct. 7, 2018. The tradition of building human towers or “castells” dates back to the 18th century and takes place during festivals in Catalonia, where “colles” or teams compete to build the tallest and most complicated towers. #APPhoto Emilio Morenatti @emilio_morenatti
A man, right, takes a photo of a car lifted into the air following an earthquake and tsunami at Talise beach in Palu, Central Sulawesi, Indonesia, Oct. 1, 2018. #APPhoto Tatan Syuflana @tatansyuf

Scenes from Capitol Hill today as Christine Blasey Ford declared to the Senate Judiciary Committee that Brett Kavanaugh sexually assaulted her at a 1980s high school gathering. Kavanaugh denied the allegations, battling to rescue his Supreme Court nomination.

Los Angeles Rams’ Lamarcus Joyner runs onto the field before an NFL football game against the Los Angeles Chargers, Sept. 23, 2018, in Los Angeles. #APPhoto Jae C. Hong @jaechongpix #AssociatedPress #LosAngeles #NFL

Anthony Torres poses for a photograph at his brother's home in Atco, N.J., Sept. 17, 2018. Torres said he was the rider caught shaving on a New Jersey Transit train in a video that went viral. #APPhoto Matt Rourke 
The truth, Torres said, is that the video captured him at a vulnerable moment. He had been homeless and staying in a shelter in New York City. He’d reached out to his family for help. A brother gave him money for a train ticket, which he was using to get to another brother in southern New Jersey. He said he left the shelter before having a chance to shower and clean up and wanted to look “presentable.” #NewJersey #NJtransit #AssociatedPress

Ultra-Orthodox Jewish men of the Vizhnitz Hassidic sect pray on a hill overlooking the Mediterranean Sea as they participate in a Tashlich ceremony in Herzeliya, Israel, Sept. 17, 2018. Tashlich, which means "to cast away" in Hebrew, is the practice in which Jews go to a large flowing body of water and symbolically "throw away" their sins by throwing a piece of bread, or similar food, into the water before the Jewish holiday of Yom Kippur, which starts at sundown Tuesday. #APPhoto Ariel Schalit @arielschalitphotos
#YomKippur #MediterraneanSea #Israel #AssociatedPress

#HurricaneFlorence #NorthCarolina #AssociatedPress

Commuters brave the rain and strong winds brought about by Typhoon Mangkhut which barreled into northeastern Philippines before dawn Sept. 15, 2018, in Manila, Philippines.  #APPhoto Bullit Marquez

The typhoon’s ferocious winds and blinding rain ripped off tin roof sheets and knocked out power as it plowed through the agricultural region. 
#TyphoonMangkhut #Philippines #AssociatedPress

The dazzling displays of color emerge amid the mud and monsoon rains of Bangladesh’s refugee camps: vibrant flower headbands and elaborately-drawn makeup worn by young Rohingya girls.
These girls are among 700,000 Rohingya Muslims who were forced to flee their homes after the military in neighboring Myanmar launched a brutal campaign of violence against the minority group last year. Many left all their cherished belongings behind, and their new lives in the cramped, chaotic camps are devoid of luxuries. But for the Islamic holiday of Eid al-Fitr, they bought makeup and headbands from vendors in the camps, hoping the adornments would help them look beautiful to relatives they visited during the holiday. #APPhoto Wong Maye-E @w0ngmayee #Rohingya #refugee #AssociatedPress

Russ Lewis covers his eyes from a gust of wind and a blast of sand as Hurricane Florence approaches Myrtle Beach, S.C., Sept. 14, 2018. #APPhoto David Goldman @apdavidgoldman
#Hurricane #SouthCarolina #AssociatedPress

Marge Brown, 65, says goodbye to her father, George Brown, 90, before he is evacuated from a healthcare home in Morehead City, N.C., Sept. 12, 2018, as Hurricane Florence approaches the east coast. "I'd like to stay and see what happens. I'm 90 plus," said Brown, a WWII veteran who says he's survived a plane crash and severe burns from a laboratory fire where he once worked. #APPhoto David Goldman @apdavidgoldman 
The outer bands of wind and rain from a weakened but still lethal Hurricane Florence began lashing North Carolina on Thursday as the monster storm moved in for a prolonged and potentially catastrophic stay along the Southeast coast that could drench the homes of as many as 10 million people. 
#HurricaneFlorence #NorthCarolina #AssociatedPress

People walk under an American flag inside the Oculus, part of the World Trade Center transportation hub, on the anniversary of 9/11 terrorist attacks in New York on Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2018. #APPhoto Craig Ruttle @rutlman #AssociatedPress

A gay rights activist celebrates after the country’s top court struck down a colonial-era law that made homosexual acts punishable by up to 10 years in prison, in New Delhi, India, Sept. 6, 2018. The court gave its ruling on a petition filed by five people who challenged the law, saying they are living in fear of being harassed and prosecuted by police. #APPhoto @altafqadri 
#LGBTQ #India #AssociatedPress

Kimberly Loring, left, touches her forehead to her little sister, Jonnilyn, 17, as she says goodbye before heading out on a search for their missing sister, Ashley, with their cousin, Lissa Loring, on the Blackfeet Indian Reservation in Browning, Mont., July 11, 2018. "I'm the older sister. I need to do this," says 24-year-old Kimberly. "I don't want to search until I'm 80. But if I have to, I will." #APPhoto David Goldman @apdavidgoldman 
Ashley HeavyRunner Loring, a 20-year-old member of the Blackfeet Nation, was last heard from around June 8, 2017. Ashley's disappearance is one small chapter in the unsettling story of missing and murdered Native American women and girls. No one knows precisely how many there are, because some cases go unreported, others aren't documented thoroughly and there isn't a specific government database tracking these cases. But one U.S. senator with victims in her home state calls this an epidemic, a long-standing problem linked to inadequate resources, outright indifference and a confusing jurisdictional maze. 
Now, in the era of #MeToo, this issue is gaining political traction as an expanding activist movement focuses on Native women, a population known to experience some of the nation's highest rates of murder, sexual violence and domestic abuse. 
#missing #BlackfeetIndianReservation #AssociatedPress

I’m Petros Giannakouris (@petrosgiannakouris giannakouris), Associated Press staff photographer based in Greece. For the next few days, I'll be taking over the @apnews Instagram feed. Greece has been relying on billions of euros in international emergency loans for the past eight years. In return for the funds, successive governments have had to impose deeply unpopular reforms, including slashing pensions and salaries, and increasing social security contributions and taxes. In the eight years of Greece’s three bailouts, the country lost a quarter of its economy, sinking it into a depression, and saw unemployment spiral to around 28 percent. Many businesses across the country shut down and many professionals moved abroad. The country defaulted on its debt, and the government imposed restrictions on financial transactions in 2015, limiting Greeks’ access to their bank accounts. Although the restrictions have eased, they have not been lifted.
Now, Greece’s third and final international bailout is ending on Aug. 20, and the country will have to raise funds on its own on the international bond markets.  These are images selected from the course of the Greek financial crisis.
Photo caption: Homeless people eat a New Year's day meal distributed by the municipality of Athens on Jan. 1, 2013. #APPhoto #Greece #Athens #bailout #AssociatedPress

Aretha Franklin, the undisputed “Queen of Soul” who sang with matchless style on such classics as “Think,” ″I Say a Little Prayer” and her signature song, “Respect,” and stood as a cultural icon around the globe, has died at age 76 from pancreatic cancer. 
Publicist Gwendolyn Quinn tells The Associated Press through a family statement that Franklin died Thursday at 9:50 a.m. at her home in Detroit. The statement said “Franklin’s official cause of death was due to advanced pancreatic cancer of the neuroendocrine type, which was confirmed by Franklin’s oncologist, Dr. Philip Phillips of Karmanos Cancer Institute” in Detroit.

On the map, the Trans-Sahara highway links Algeria’s Mediterranean coast to the distant Atlantic shore in Nigeria. 
Once a well-worn roadway for overlander tourists, the highway’s 4,500 kilometers (2,800 miles) are a favored path for migrants heading north in hopes of a better life — and more recently, thousands who are being expelled south from Algeria. 
The grand monotony of the bare Tenere desert is broken by the carcasses of abandoned vehicles, lone trees able to survive on the barest whisper of water, rusted water barrels and sand-swept truck tires used as distance markers. 
For more, visit apimagesblog.com.

#APPhotos @jeromedelay

There was nothing to prepare. There wasn’t even any notice a visitor was coming. It was 2:30 on a weekday afternoon, and some women were roused from sleep by the sound of their cell door unlocking. They were asked if they’d pose for a portrait. 
The setting was the Campbell County Jail, where the last time these female inmates looked into a camera, their mug shots were being taken. Some women were in for theft; others for drug possession or parole violations. For all, this stint behind bars was just the latest downward turn in a cycle of addiction and incarceration. 
More than a decade ago, there were rarely more than 10 women in this rural Tennessee jail. Now the population is routinely around 60. The opioid crisis is putting more women behind bars across the U.S., tearing apart families and squeezing communities that lack treatment programs and permanent solutions. 
The women say being locked up does little to prepare them for life on the outside, where friends - and in some cases, family - might lure them back into drugs again. 
Photos by David Goldman @apdavidgoldman 
#opioids #portraits #film #CampbellCountyJail #prison #APPhoto #AssociatedPress

Yemen’s civil war has chewed up and spat out a generation of youth. Fighters on all sides are often minors, some as young as 12, dragged into what many see as a cynical fight between Iranian-backed rebels known as Houthis and a U.S.-backed coalition led by Saudi Arabia nominally supporting the government. Three years of war with no end in sight has wrecked Yemen, causing death, displacement, economic collapse, hunger and disease. 
In this Feb. 17, 2018 photo, 21 year-old Osama Ahmed, who fought during the '2015 battle of Aden' holds his rifle in his bedroom, at his home in Aden, Yemen. "As a Yemeni citizen you can't leave the country - we are listed as terrorists - we had dreams and wanted to do things with our lives. There are no opportunity for the youth, we just want to live in peace without violence," he said. #APPhoto @narimanelmofty #Yemen #starvation #famine #YemenDirtyWar #photojournalism

Hello @apnews followers. 
My name is Nariman El-Mofty (@narimanelmofty) and I'm an Associated Press photojournalist based in Cairo. 
For the past two days, I took over the @apnews @instagram feed to share some of my recent work in Yemen. This is my last image. 
Three years into a civil war, mothers from Yemen are often the only defense against the hunger that has killed thousands. They skip meals, they sleep to escape the gnawing in their stomachs. They hide bony faces and emaciated bodies in voluminous black abaya robes and veils. 
Umm Mizrah who weighs 38 kilograms (84 pounds), is severely undernourished and nearly into the second trimester of her pregnancy, reveals her collarbones to be photographed, at the Aden Hospital, Feb. 13, 2018, Yemen.  #APPhoto @narimanelmofty  #Yemen #starvation #famine #YemenDirtyWar #photojournalism

Three years into a civil war, Yemen is starving and could soon start to see widespread death from famine. Houthi rebels hold the country’s north and a Saudi-led coalition, armed and backed by the U.S., has sought to bomb the rebels into submission with a relentless air campaign in support of the Yemeni government. 
In this photo, an empty field on a street, Feb. 12, 2018, Khoukha, Yemen. Khoukha was liberated from the Houthis in December by coalition-backed forces marching up the coast. In rebel hands, the town had been directly connected to Hodeida port further north, the biggest entryway for international aid into Yemen. #APPhoto @narimanelmofty  #Yemen #starvation #famine #YemenDirtyWar #photojournalism

Hello @apnews followers. 
My name is Nariman El-Mofty (@narimanelmofty) and I'm an Associated Press photojournalist based in Cairo. I'm currently taking over the @apnews @instagram feed to share some of my recent work in Yemen. 
Three years into a civil war, Yemen is starving and could soon start to see widespread death from famine. Houthi rebels hold the country’s north and a Saudi-led coalition, armed and backed by the U.S., has sought to bomb the rebels into submission with a relentless air campaign in support of the Yemeni government. 
In this photo, homeless children stand on the road from Khoukha to Taiz, Feb. 12, 2018, Yemen. Nearly a third of Yemen’s population _ 8.4 million of its 29 million people _ are one step away from famine. That number grew by a quarter over the past year, as increasing numbers of people lost their ability to support themselves. A wider swath of the population, 18 million, needs some sort of food assistance, according to the World Food Program.  #APPhoto @narimanelmofty #Yemen #starvation #famine #YemenDirtyWar #photojournalism

Hello @apnews followers. 
My name is Nariman El-Mofty (@narimanelmofty) and I'm an Associated Press photojournalist based in Cairo. I'm currently taking over the @apnews @instagram feed for the next two days to share some of my recent work in Yemen. “Take our photographs, write, tell the world our story, send our message out - we are trapped, do your job,” women from Yemen screamed as we reported on the world’s worst humanitarian crisis from a hospital in Al-Khoukha, Hodeida, where there is no aid, food or water. Mothers carrying babies mobbed the nutrition center at the main hospital in the small town on the Red Sea, expecting to receive monthly allotments of baby formula and nutrient supplies. They left empty-handed. Some of the women, cloaked in black abayas, pushed and shoved feebly. But most were too weak to complain and silently shuffled away. 
Sawda Mohammed Khalil holds her malnourished daughter as they wait for treatment at the Khoukha Hospital, Feb. 12, 2018, Yemen. Doctors estimate 40 percent of the children in the town suffer from malnutrition. Barefoot children fill the center’s corridors, many visibly emaciated, some with malaria or cholera. Some can barely stand. 
#APPhoto @narimanelmofty #Yemen #Abyan #starvation #famine #AssociatedPress #YemenDirtyWar #photojournalism

Hello @apnews followers.

I'm currently taking over the @apnews @instagram feed for the next two days to share some of my recent work in Yemen. 
Save the Children late last year estimated that 50,000 children may have died in Yemen in 2017 of extreme hunger or disease, given that up to 30 percent of children with untreated cases of severe acute malnutrition die. 
Nine-month old Galila, who suffers from malnutrition, weeps as she is weighed and measured, at the Stabilization Nutritional Therapeutic center, Feb. 12, 2018, Khoukha, Yemen. The baby girl caught malaria and began to fall in weight. Now she is all of 4.5 kilograms (9.9 pounds), compared to the average of 6 to 8 kilograms (13-17 pounds) for a 9-month-old girl. Her mother is tiny as well, ravaged by giving up food for a family that is constantly growing. #APPhoto @narimanelmofty

Hello @apnews followers. 
My name is Nariman El-Mofty (@narimanelmofty) and I'm an Associated Press photojournalist based in Cairo. 
I'll be taking over the @apnews @instagram feed for the next two days to share some of my recent work in Yemen. 
Three years into Yemen’s civil war, and the results are disastrous: Yemen is starving. With a population of 29 million, its people are on the edge of famine. Around 2.9 million Yemeni women and children are acutely malnourished. The country's three-year stalemated war has killed more than 10,000 people, displaced 3 million in the Arab world's poorest country and increased pressure on an already-tenuous food supply. 
In this photo, Hagar Yahia holds her daughter Awsaf, a thin 5-year-old who is getting no more than 800 calories a day from bread and tea, half the normal amount for a girl her age, Feb. 9, 2018, Abyan, Yemen. Yahia, a mother of eight breaks down in tears talking about her family’s deprivation. Late last year, as fighting closed in on Hayis, they fled more than 200 miles, eventually ending up in the village of Red Star on the Arabian Sea coast in the south. Ever since they’ve struggled to find enough food.  #APPhoto @narimanelmofty  #Yemen #Abyan #starvation #famine #AssociatedPress #NarimanElMofty #YemenDirtyWar #photojournalism

The battle to save Africa's elephants appears to be gaining momentum in Mikumi, where killings are declining and some populations are starting to grow again.

As part of the conservation effort, a yearlong program was created to collar and track 60 elephants in and around Tanzania’s Selous Game Reserve, widely acknowledged as ‘Ground Zero’ in the poaching that has decimated Africa’s elephants in recent years. 
The Associated Press traveled to the area to witness some of the continent’s elephant conservation, with killings declining and some herds showing signs of recovery. Legal ivory markets are shrinking worldwide, and law enforcement has broken up some key trafficking syndicates, say experts.

But it’s far too early to declare a turnaround. Poachers are moving to new areas and traffickers are adapting, aided by entrenched corruption. The rate of annual elephant losses still exceeds the birth rate. And the encroachment of human settlements is reducing the animals’ range.

Photos Ben Curtis

On April 4, 1968, fifty years ago today, a single bullet fired in Memphis, Tennessee, changed the world. Martin Luther King Jr. was shot and killed on the balcony of the Lorraine Motel after helping to lead a peaceful march in support of the sanitation strikes.

The civil rights leader had carried the banner for the causes of social justice – organizing protests, leading marches and making powerful speeches exposing the scourges of segregation, poverty and racism. 
Photos: Hosea Williams, Jesse Jackson, Martin Luther King Jr., and Ralph Abernathy on the balcony the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, King's last public appearance before his assassination,  newspaper headlines the day after King's death, Coretta Scott King and her daughter, Bernice, during the funeral of King, a scene from outside the funeral, and soldiers attend a memorial for King while stationed in Vietnam.

As Israel heads into its fifth consecutive year of drought, the Sea of Galilee stands at a century low, much of the Jordan River is a fetid trickle and the Dead Sea is rapidly shrinking.

The biblical bodies of waters — pilgrimage sites for baptisms and beach parties alike — are crucial to the survival and stability of Israel, Jordan and the Palestinians. But more and more of the river the ancient Israelites crossed to enter the Holy Land is drying up — the result of climate change, growing populations and the increasing use of its water for agriculture.

The nation’s homeless population increased this year for the first time since 2010, driven by a surge in the number of people living on the streets in Los Angeles and other West Coast cities. 
The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development released its annual Point in Time count Wednesday, a report that showed nearly 554,000 homeless people across the country during local tallies conducted in January. That figure is up nearly 1 percent from 2016. Of that total, 193,000 people had no access to nightly shelter and instead were staying in vehicles, tents, the streets and other places considered uninhabitable. The unsheltered figure is up by more than 9 percent compared to two years ago. Increases are higher in several West Coast cities, where the explosion in homelessness has prompted at least 10 city and county governments to declare states of emergency since 2015.

For the full story, visit https://apnews.com/tag/HomelessCrisis

In this Thursday Nov. 30, 2017 photo, people take part in an annual parade celebrating the birth anniversary of Prophet Muhammad, in Sale, near Rabat, Morocco. #APPhoto @mosaabelshamy 
A large parade with historic roots takes place in the Moroccan city of Sale each year to mark the birth of the Prophet Muhammad, an occasion Muslims around the world observe as Mawlid an-Nabi.
Sale, a bustling city of about 890,000 residents across the Bouregreg River from the kingdom’s capital, Rabat, transforms as residents join the procession. A Saadian dynasty monarch who ruled Morocco in the 1570s is believed to have imported the procession from the Ottoman Empire.
The parade has been held continuously since then. Men carrying wooden structures that resemble the minarets on mosques lead it off. Colorful candles arranged like mosaic tiles and spelling out the names of Allah, Muhammad, and members of the Moroccan royal family adorn the towers.
Children in traditional dress and musicians with horns and drums take part in the choreographed spectacle, which swells in size as people chase and merge with the festive throng moving through the old medina quarter. Families take to the streets and cheer from balconies.
The parade that takes place on the eve of the date recognized as Muhammad’s birthday — Dec. 1 this year — is the main event of a weeklong festival that gives local bands the chance to perform and receive tips from patrons.

Rohingya Muslims have faced state-supported discrimination in the predominantly Buddhist country for decades. Though members of the ethnic minority first arrived generations ago, Rohingya were stripped of their citizenship in 1982, denying them almost all rights and rendering them stateless. They cannot travel freely, practice their religion, or work as teachers or doctors, and they have little access to medical care, food or education. 
Caption: Rohingya muslim woman Dildar Begum and her daughter Noor Kalima, recovers at Sadar Hospital in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh, Wednesday, Sept. 27, 2017. Begum and her daughter Noor Kalima, got stabbed by Myanmar soldiers and her husband was killed. #APPhoto @daryasinap

#Rohingya #Myanmar #Bangladesh #DildarBegum #NoorKalima #SadarHospital #CoxsBazar #DarYasin #AssociatedPress

The exodus of Rohingya Muslims started Aug. 25 when insurgents attacked dozens of police posts in Myanmar. The retribution from Myanmar’s authorities was swift and brutal. Hundreds of Rohingya villages in Rakhine state have been set on fire. Fleeing Rohingya have told stories of arson and rape and shootings by Myanmar soldiers and Buddhist mobs. The violence, which the U.N. describes as ethnic cleansing, has pushed more than 600,000 Rohingya into Bangladesh. 
For the next few days, we will share photos and stories of the Rohingya exodus from AP South Asia News Director and AP photojournalist Bernat Armangué (@bernatarmangue) and AP photographer Dar Yasin (@daryasinap). Caption: A Rohingya Muslim man stretches his arms out for food distributed by local volunteers, with bags of puffed rice stuffed into his vest at Kutupalong, Bangladesh, Saturday, Sept. 9, 2017. #APPhoto @bernatarmangue

#Rohingya #man #Myanmar #Bangladesh #Rakhine #BernatArmangue #DarYasin #AssociatedPress

Although Rohingya Muslims have lived in Myanmar for decades, the country’s Buddhist majority still sees them as invaders from Bangladesh. The government denies them basic rights, and the United Nations has called them the most persecuted minority in the world. Just since August, after their homes were torched by Buddhist mobs and soldiers, more than 600,000 Rohingya have risked the trip to Bangladesh.

Caption: A Rohingya Muslim Kefayet Ullah stands next to the graves of his 25-year-old brother Jarullah and 21-year-old sister-in-law Ayesha Bibi at a makeshift cemetery near Cox's Bazar's Tumbru area, Bangladesh. The family had already been in their hasty shelter on the mud bank near Naf River for days before Jarullah and Bibi decided to go slip back across the border to their village in Myanmar briefly for a quick bath and clean clothes before Eid, only to be killed by Myanmar soldiers and Buddhist monks in an attack witnessed by their cousin. Ullah said he couldn’t bear the thought of leaving his loved ones behind, and so risked his life to return and carry their bodies back so they could bury them in peace. #APPhoto @bernatarmangue

#Rohingya #Myanmar #Bangladesh #BernatArmangue #DarYasin #AssociatedPress

Rohingya have fled en masse to escape persecution before. Hundreds of thousands left Myanmar in 1978 and again in the early 1990s, though policies subsequently allowed many to return. Communal violence in 2012, as the country was transitioning from a half-century of dictatorship to democracy, sent another 100,000 fleeing by boat. 
For the next few days, we will share photos and stories of the Rohingya exodus from AP South Asia News Director and AP photojournalist Bernat Armangué (@bernatarmangue) and AP photographer Dar Yasin (@daryasinap). As part of a project looking at the homeless crisis on the West Coast, AP photographer Jae C. Hong (@jaechongpix) traveled to Seattle, San Francisco and to Los Angeles to shoot intimate portraits of the people with no permanent homes. He used a special lens to focus on their eyes. For the next few days, we are sharing some of the stories those people told:

James Harris 
Age: 54

Home: A tent in Hollywood, California

James Harris likes to open with “God bless you” before asking for money. It makes him feel better to offer something in exchange for a handout. “It’s hard panhandling and taking things from people,” he said.

Harris said he has had AIDS for 30 years, he said. When medication stopped working, he got depressed and was evicted. Now he feels like an outcast, vulnerable and struggling to survive. “I’ve been beaten, robbed, chased,” he said. “People steal your tents and your tarps and your clothes. I’ve lost everything I owned.” He’s hoping that as a veteran he can get permanent housing, though he missed an earlier opportunity because a stint in a shelter disqualified him from being considered chronically homeless.

He gets by on $900 a month from Social Security and whatever he can scrounge up. A little extra cash might get him some crack to smoke at night. “I put needs first, drugs last,” he said.

He spent the remaining $105 from a recent check on a suit and put on makeup to look like Two-Face, the villain from Batman comics. He wanted to “make an honest living” with others dressed as superheroes or movie characters jostling for tips on Hollywood Boulevard.

But it didn’t go well. He said he didn’t earn a dime.

Story by Jae C. Hong and @brianmelley 
For more, visit APImagesblog.com

#homeless #crisis #WestCoast #JamesHarris #JaeCHong #TheAssociatedPress #portrait #photojournalism #California #Hollywood #LosAngeles

As part of a project looking at the homeless crisis on the West Coast, AP photographer Jae C. Hong (@jaechongpix) traveled to Seattle, San Francisco and to Los Angeles to shoot intimate portraits of the people with no permanent homes. He used a special lens to focus on their eyes. For the next few days, we are sharing some of the stories those people told:

John Ruiz

Age: 9 
Home: An RV with his parents and siblings in Mountain View, California, the home of Google

The fourth-grader dreams of going to college. He knows it’s the path to a better job and a home that’s not on four wheels.
His father is a minimum-wage landscaper who moved the family to an aging camper after they were evicted from an apartment where the rent kept going up, nearing $3,000 a month. His mother is five months pregnant.
The family parks the recreational vehicle outside an apartment building where three bedroom apartments rent for up to $6,000 a month.

John Ruiz’s friends at school were surprised to hear he lived in an RV. “I thought they were going to laugh, but they were OK with it,” he said.

The worst thing about living in a camper is that it’s cramped, hot in summer and cold in winter. He and his brother have to walk to get water and dump their trash.
“At least we have a home we can live in,” he said. “I have a bunch of toys. Mostly the good part is there’s a little stove where we can eat.” John dreams of his family having a successful life together and maybe ending up in a mansion _ a home that might have a swimming pool and backyard. Or at least one big enough to have his own room.
“I want to have a happy life,” he said.

Story by Jae C. Hong and @brianmelley 
For more, visit APImagesblog.com
