Greetings @ap.images followers! This is @jaechongpix an AP staff photographer based in Los Angeles. This week I am posting an instagram #takeover of my recent photo essay on homelessness in Hawaii. 
Hawaii has long been known as a tropical paradise, but in recent years another image has intruded into the state's carefully crafted one of idyllic beaches and relaxing resorts: homelessness. The number of homeless people has grown in recent years, leaving the state with 487 homeless per 100,000 people, the nation's highest rate per capita, above New York and Nevada, according to federal statistics.

In this photo, a homeless man drinks water while sitting on the beach at Ala Moana Beach Park located near Waikiki in Honolulu. Last year, after visitors began complaining about too many homeless people living near Waikiki Beach, Mayor Kirk Caldwell proposed a ban on sitting and lying down on sidewalks in the area. Letters from Hyatt Regency, Trump International, Hilton Worldwide and other major resorts poured in supporting the proposed ban. #APPhoto by @jaechongpix

Pilgrims pray and pay tribute at a statue of Padre Cicero at the public square in Juazeiro do Norte, Brazil. The Rev. Cicero Romao Batista was born in 1844 and died at age 90 in this arid, impoverished part of northeast Brazil. His followers say that during a Mass celebrated by the priest in 1889, a woman receiving communion declared that the Host had turned to blood in her mouth. People called it a miracle, but the Vatican was displeased and suspended him. #APPhoto by @leocorrea21

This is @dariolopezm a staff #photojournalist with the AP based in Mexico City, posting an #instagram #takeover of my photo essay on @ap.images about Mexico’s Other Disappeared. This is the last photo of the takeover. Thank you for following. 
Matias Fermin Montano, left, and Agustina Ramirez Nemesio hold up a photo of their son, Margarito Fermin Ramirez in Iguala, Mexico, June 30, 2015. Their son, a cabdriver, was 42 years old when he disappeared on Dec. 2, 2012. He left to drive his taxi that night and never returned. The car was later found abandoned. #APPhoto by @dariolopezm

Today marks the one-year anniversary of the disappearance of 43 students from a rural teachers college in southern Mexico. The Associated Press spent the last six months documenting the stories of the so-called “other disappeared” of Guerrero, who surged forward in the wake of the students’ disappearances to say that they too had lost loved ones.

This is @dariolopezm a staff #photojournalist with the AP based in Mexico City, posting an #instagram #takeover of my photo essay on @ap.images about Mexico’s Other Disappeared. 
In this June 1, 2015 photo, relatives of Victor Albarran Varela look at a photo of him at his home in Cocula, Mexico. On July 1, 2013 the explosion of gunfire echoed from the center of this town in the predawn stillness. A convoy of armed men had arrived in town and once they had left, 17 residents including Albarran, had disappeared, never to be seen again. They are among the 25,000 Mexicans who have disappeared since 2007, according to the government’s count. Albarran was 15 when he was taken. #APPhoto by @dariolopezm

The world, and even most of Mexico, paid little attention to Iguala and Cocula until 43 students from a rural teachers' college disappeared on Sept. 26, 2014  allegedly killed and then their bodies burned by a drug gang with the aid of local police at a garbage dump in Cocula, according to a federal investigation. Two months after the students disappeared many other families in the area began looking for clandestine graves and have come forward to tell their stories, emboldened by the attention focused on the missing students. Their message was simple: there are many more missing. They are “the other disappeared.” See the interactive project: http://interactives.ap.org/2015/mexico-disappeared/?locale=en

This is @dariolopezm a staff #photojournalist with the AP based in Mexico City, posting an #instagram #takeover on @ap.images of my photo essay about Mexico’s Other Disappeared.

In this Aug. 19, 2015 photo, two crosses painted in the ground mark the site where two students were killed and 43 others were taken away in Iguala, Mexico on Sept. 26, 2014. According to a federal investigation, the students were taken by police and then handed over to a local drug gang who allegedly killed them and burned the bodies. The incident cast national and international attention on Iguala emboldening hundreds of local families to come forward and speak up about their own missing relatives.  #APPhoto by @dariolopezm

The world, and even most of Mexico, paid little attention to Iguala until 43 students from a rural teachers' college disappeared on Sept. 26, 2014. Two months after the students disappeared many other families in the area began looking for clandestine graves and have come forward to tell their stories, emboldened by the international attention focused on the missing students. Their message was simple: there are many more missing. They are “the other disappeared.” See the interactive project: http://interactives.ap.org/2015/mexico-disappeared/?locale=en

This is @dariolopezm a staff #photojournalist with the AP based in Mexico City, posting an #instagram #takeover on @ap.images of my photo essay about Mexico’s Other Disappeared.

In this Aug. 18, 2015 photo, the day ends in Iguala, located in a poor region of the southern Mexican state of Guerrero. The city was thrust into the national and international limelight when three students were killed and 43 others disappeared. At least 292 people have been added to the list of missing from the area since the 43 disappeared there on Sept. 26, 2014. #APPhoto by @dariolopezm

The disappearance of the 43 students gave hundreds of families in and around the city the courage to look for their own disappeared. They gathered at a church. They swallowed their fear and went into the mountains in search of secret graves. They have found 60 graves and theremains of 104 people. Only six of them have been identified and returned to their families. The Associated Press interviewed relatives of 158 missing people from Iguala, only a portion of those who have reported their cases at the church. Some of the families did not want to be photographed, in most cases because they remain very frightened. At total of 79 portraits with audio quotes could be completed. See the full interactive project here: http://interactives.ap.org/2015/mexico-disappeared/?locale=en

Hi everybody. This is @tstargardter, photo editor at AP's Latin American and Caribbean photo desk. This is it. Our last day of our four-day #takeover of the @ap.images Instagram feed. 
Parting shot. 
They were seen but not heard. Despite the security efforts of what appeared to be thousands of plainclothes and uniformed security officers, two dissidents managed to make themselves known as the Pope arrived for a Mass at Havana’s Plaza of the Revolution. The two men were wrestled to the ground by security officers as they yelled and tried to throw leaflets into the air. Nobody managed to hear what they where saying, or read what were on their leaflets they tried, in vain, to distribute. 
Caption:  Two unidentified men are taken away by security officers after they threw leaflets as Pope Francis arrives for a Mass at Revolution Plaza in Havana, Cuba, Sunday Sept. 20, 2015. Francis will not be meeting with dissidents during his visit, sparking critiques from the political opposition who say they feel let down by an institution they believe should help push for greater freedom in Cuba. (AP Photo/Ramon Espinosa)

Adios from Mexico City! This is @lesliemazoch, photo editor at the AP's Latin America and Caribbean photo desk. Today's the last day of our editors' four-day #takeover of the @ap.images Instagram feed related to coverage of Pope Francis in Cuba. 
LOVE the expression on this woman's face, and her "hands-free" flags-in-hair look, captured by Desmond Boylan @desboylan. I was surprised to learn these women weren't Cuban, but from Angola! They're doing their residency at a hospital located along the pontiff's route from Havana’s airport right after he first arrived in Cuba. After free medical school, they'll return to their native Angola to practice. 
We're at the culmination of day four of editing hundreds of images from a handful of photographers. Staffers, freelancers and pool photographers. Photos to the wire. Photos to the archive. Photos that never saw the light of day. 
It was a great exercise in working on fast-forward. Editing, caption writing, communicating with other formats. Now Francis in the U.S., where our colleagues are geared up to take on the second leg of his trip. 
Caption: Medical staff from a nearby hospital, wearing Vatican and Cuban flags in their hair, look at their selfies while waiting for Pope Francis' motorcade in Havana, Cuba, Saturday, Sept. 19, 2015. (AP Photo/Desmond Boylan)

Our editors' four-day #takeover of AP Images Instagram feed is about to come to an end. Thank you all for your interest and comments, I enjoyed the engagement and it was such a thrill to see all those "likes" flood in.

There was an agreement to post in the square format, but I have to break that promise for my last post, because I couldn't bear to crop this image, yet I wanted to share with you the genius of Enric Marti's photographic eye. @enricfmarti, a veteran photographer who cut his teeth working in conflict zones, is now the regional director of photography and was on the ground in Cuba for the papal visit. He mostly does administrative stuff, managing photographers and editors over a breadth of 30 countries, but every now and then he shoots too. It's true that he is a genius, and I'm not just saying that because he's my boss.

This scene of residents waiting for the popemobile to ride past is a gem of a photo. It's delightful, unexpected, genuine, and the framing is brilliant. Look at all those personalities. After so many images of Pope Francis I was happy to see an unchoreographed scene from the sidelines. It's so easy to imagine being there in Holguin, watching from across the street. I can almost feel the rain that's about to come down on them.

Hi everybody. This is @tstargardter, photo editor at the AP's Latin American and Caribbean photo desk. Today is my turn, as we continue our four-day #takeover of the @ap.images Instagram feed.

It seems that every time that the Pope arrives to a new country his skull cap flies away in the wind. Same thing happened in his last trip to South America. This time in Cuba was no different.
The wind carries away Pope Francis' cap as he deplanes in Havana, Cuba, Saturday, Sept. 19, 2015. The pope begins a 10-day trip to Cuba and the United States on Saturday, embarking on his first trip to the onetime Cold War foes after helping to nudge forward their historic rapprochement. (AP Photo/Ramon Espinosa)

Reconstituted Christ. A nice metaphor for the return of the Catholic Church to communist Cuba.
In this Thursday, Sept. 17, 2015 photo, a worker prepares to fit a wooden arm onto a Christ statue during preparations of the altar where Pope Francis will celebrate Mass in the Plaza of the Revolution, in Havana, Cuba. Hi everybody. This is @tstargardter, photo editor at AP's Latin American and Caribbean photo desk. Today is my turn, as we continue our four-day #takeover of the @ap.images Instagram feed.
This is the second time I cover a Papal visit from the editor’s side of the event. I covered Pope John Paul’s II multiple visits to Central America in the 1990’s as a photojournalist and it was a grueling experience. Now that I am on the editor’s side, it is more of a mental exercise. You shepherd the images along and make sure everything is all right. 
If you see me a little disheveled in my portrait, it’s because I am just recovering from a case of influenza, and I am still not feeling quite 100%. #photojournalism #fotoperiodismo #office #desk #Mexico#gatekeeper #headquarters #religion #papa #pope#popeFrancis #papaFrancisco #Catholic #papacuba#walkwithFrancis #habemuspapam #cuba #havana #PopeinCuba#popevisit2015 #papalvisit2015 #faithful #catholicchurch#pontifex #lahabana #saturday #instagram

Hello from Mexico City! This is @lesliemazoch, photo editor at the AP's Latin America and Caribbean photo desk. This week we're trying something new: an editors' four-day #takeover of the@ap.images Instagram feed. Today I'll be sharing photos and some anecdotes related to coverage of Pope Francis in Cuba. 
Thank you Alessandra Tarantino @alexiati00 for making my day! Alessandra's based in Rome and has temporarily joined our Cuba photo team to cover the pope, at least her sixth trip with two pontiffs around the globe.

As I edited her coverage this morning, I asked her if she was cool with my crop of one of her images. It was the second time I'd proposed a crop and asked to see an image without her crop. After seeing it, she answered: "Nice! You can crop everything you want! It's an honor to be cropped by you!" It's nice to be trusted with someone else's work, but since it's the photographer's byline published with the photo, not mine, I believe it's only right for them to sign-off on it. For me it's also important to chip away at the "us vs. them" mentality of photographers and editors, and be the kind of editor I'd like to work with.

The photo in question was a flag waving shot, but I prefer to share this daily life scene by Alessandra of a market vendor prepping onions hours before Pope Francis landed on Saturday. It's as if the man is stepping out of the shadows, symbolic of Cuba reemerging as Havana and Washington reestablish relations. US tourists can finally visit this hidden treasure just miles off their own coast. It also suggests the mystery of hidden worlds and the secrets we all keep.

Hello from Mexico City! This is @lesliemazoch, photo editor at the AP's Latin America and Caribbean photo desk. This week we're trying something new: an editors' four-day #takeover of the @ap.images Instagram feed. Today I'll be sharing photos and some anecdotes related to coverage of Pope Francis in Cuba.
This image by Eduardo Verdugo @eduardoverdugot taken in rural Cuba caught my attention. First, I'm a sucker for female religious icons. I suspect it has to do with my doll collecting hobby and my appreciation for the many incarnations of the Virgin Mary as Christianity's modern day Mother Earth. And get a load of those finger nails! Perfectly color-coordinated with the Virgin of Charity's purple and gold robe. 
She's the island's patron saint, the protector of sailors and copper miners. She's also the sister goddess to "Ochun," the Afro-Cuban goddess of rivers, maternity and love. Long live the sisterhood! 
Caption - Yelenis Teruel Salas shows her key chain of the Virgin of Charity outside the San Isidoro Cathedral where she prayed as part of her 15th birthday celebration, or "quinceañera" in Holguin, Cuba, Saturday, Sept. 19, 2015, on the day Pope Francis arrived to island. Hello from Mexico City! This is @lesliemazoch, photo editor at the AP's Latin America and Caribbean photo desk. This week we're trying something new: an editors' four-day #takeover of the@ap.images Instagram feed. Today I'll be sharing photos and some anecdotes related to Pope Francis in Cuba coverage.

This image stood out to me while editing a photo gallery by Ramon Espinosa @aprespinosa about the fusion of Catholic and African religions brought by slaves to the Caribbean centuries ago, known as Santeria. 
Afro-Cuban rituals are rich in pageantry and each person on this throne has a meaning. The woman at right in a white jumpsuit is pregnant, symbolizing life, on the throne made for the woman at center who's going through a series of rituals to become a Yoruba priestess. Her mother sits at left, representing a woman who's already given life. 
Her dress and crown are the very same color worn by Cuba's patron saint, Our Lady of Charity. In fact, one of her initiation rites includes praying to this Christian icon. It's fascinating how spirituality in Cuba is expressed in many ways, where a variety of beliefs are accepted and mixed together in a country that for decades was officially an atheist state. 
Caption: In this photo taken on Sept. 11, one week before the pope's arrival, Marisa Ramirez Gutierrez, standing center, holds still on her throne dressed in the robe of the "Iyawo," or bride, at her home in Havana, Cuba. Gutierrez's other initiation rituals include a dip in a river, sitting for an entire day with the pregnant woman, a celebratory dinner party with family and friends, and leaving herbal offerings at a local market. Hello from Mexico City! This is @lesliemazoch, photo editor at the AP's Latin American and Caribbean photo desk. This week we're trying something new: an editors' four-day#takeover of the@ap.images Instagram feed. Today I'll be sharing photos and some anecdotes related to Pope Francis in Cuba coverage.

Although the pope is the man of the hour, I get the biggest kick out of the images that show what's going on around him. The people. Their expressions. The streets. The decorations. Landscape views that give those of us who aren't there in the flesh a sense of what it's like to be at almost 90% humidity in the Caribbean. I'm also fascinated with Cubans who fuse Catholic and African faiths. Today I'll share a few that caught my eye.

My portrait was taken by AP photographer Marco Ugarte, which I then amplified on my monitor to show you my workspace, decorated with Mexican rag dolls, Our Lady of Guadalupe and my ever near tea mug. This portrait was actually the idea of colleague Anita Baca @flacabaca. She's full of good ones!

Saludos a todos! This is Anita Baca (@flacabaca) photo editor based in Mexico City for the AP's Latin American and Caribbean photo desk. This week we are trying something new with an editors' four-day #takeover @ap.images Instagram feed. We will be sharing photos and some anecdotes related to our pope in Cuba coverage.

3 degrees of separation.

This sort of picture goes into my mundane yet beautiful images' file. They're the ones that surprise me with their quiet, simple elegance and bring to the fore the behind the scenes of the making of big happenings.

It's so easy to forget about the anonymous worker bees who make these events seamless.

The embroidery on the cassock represents the Virgin of Charity of Cobre, Cuba's patron saint. While this version of the Virgin Mary is recognized by the Catholic Church, she is also adored by practitioners of Cuban Santeria, who associate her with the Yoruba deity Ochun, goddess of sweet water and gold. Pope Francis will be the third pontiff to make the trek to far-eastern Cuba to visit the religious icon. Unlike Pope John Paul II, Francis will visit the sanctuary in the foothills of the Sierra Maestra. During the historic 1998 papal visit the 16-inch figure was taken from its santuary and taken to Santiago de Cuba for a coronation ceremony, where John Paul placed a crown on the doll-sized statue, and then put an even smaller crown on the infant Jesus she bears in her arms.

In this March 25, 2012 file photo, a woman irons a cassock to be used by a priest who will accompany Pope Benedict in the celebration of Mass at the cathedral in Santiago de Cuba, Cuba. (AP Photo/Ramon Espinosa)

Saludos a todos! This is Anita Baca (@flacabaca) photo editor based in Mexico City for the AP's Latin American and Caribbean photo desk. This week we are trying something new with an editors' four-day #takeover of @ap.images Instagram feed. We will be sharing photos and some anecdotes related to our pope in Cuba coverage.

Generally speaking, papal visits are a big deal. But the pope's visit to Cuba on Jan. 21-25,1998 was a HUGE deal. A frail-looking Pope John Paul II was met on the tarmac by Fidel Castro, the leader of a communist government that had once banned Catholic schools and sent priests, including the current archbishop of Havana to prison or work camps.
And well, I missed it. It barely registers for me as I was busy nursing my newborn baby daughter in Nicaragua. I had given birth just nine days earlier. She's 17 now and makes her own lunches.

This time I will be fully tuned-in when Pope Francis arrives in Havana where he'll find a more influential church since John Paul's prophetic words during that historic visit, "May Cuba, with all its magnificent potential, open itself up to the world, and may the world open itself up to Cuba." The serious work begins this Sunday starting at 7am, with all hands on deck. Just to give you an idea of how serious, on Sundays the LatAm photo desk in Mexico City usually opens at midday, and only for eight hours, with one photo editor. So you could say we are tripling our efforts.

We are expecting a whole lot of images. You will be seeing some of our favorites in this #takeover Stay tuned.

In this Jan. 21,1998 file photo, Cuba's President Fidel Castro, and Pope John Paul II check the time during a welcoming ceremony in Havana, Cuba. Saludos a todos! This is Anita Baca (@flacabaca) photo editor based in Mexico City for the AP's Latin American and Caribbean photo desk. This week we are trying something new with an editors' four-day #takeover of @ap.images Instagram feed. We will be sharing photos and some anecdotes related to our pope in Cuba coverage.

For me, there is nothing like being in a newsroom in the middle of a breaking news event, just like that March two years ago. "It's Bergoglio!" someone shouted. Wait. What?! Wait. Oh no. Oh yes. We were stunned as we stood before the TV as the news was announced right in the middle of AP regional headquarters in Mexico City. Like many, we were interested in knowing who the new pope would be, not so much expecting to spend the next few weeks reporting on this man who some referred to as the "slum bishop." Albeit a contender, Bergoglio was a longshot. I think his odds were like 25-1. Truth be told, we had very little on the Argentine cardinal who would be pope.

Before March 13, 2013, a search for "Jorge Bergoglio" in the massive vault of AP Images would have brought up 20 hits, at best. Today plug in "Jorge Bergoglio" and the search will bring up over 600 hits. But nothing compares to the more than 21,000 hits for "Pope Francis," the last I looked. More now to be sure. 
Hey, how did I get inside my computer. ^_^ I uploaded a photo of me, made by @lesliemazoch and turned it into a screen saver, and then photographed my desk using my #iPhone. Leslie is the desk supervisor and you will be seeing her takeover posts on Sunday.

Hello everyone, this is Gregorio Borgia (@gregorioborgia), Associated Press photojournalist based in Rome. This week, I am taking over @ap.images Instagram feed to share photos from Europe's mounting migrant crisis. More than 300,000 people have sought to cross the Mediterranean Sea so far in 2015, up from 219,000 in all of last year, as European authorities grapple with the largest influx since World War II. Recently, I have been at sea documenting migrant search and rescue missions in the mediterranean sea. During this assignment they rescued 721 migrants and recovered six bodies off the Libyan coasts. 
In this photo, a Norwegian sailor aboard of the Siem Pilot looks at the Italian Coast Guard Ship Dattilo during a migrant search and rescue mission. #APPhoto by @gregorioborgia

Hola todos this is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an Instagram takeover this week from my photo essay on California's drought and its effects on a tiny Central Valley community known as Okieville. This is my last post, thank you all for your likes and comments! Stay tuned for more takeovers from AP photogs based around the world!

In this picture, Serenity Palomera, 3, laughs as she shares a bath with her cousin in ankle-deep water at their home in Okieville. At play in the water, the girls often drag out their bath time, opting to slosh around for a long as possible before bedtime. Washing two kids at the same time saves water for the family since their well dried, but for Serenity, it's just more fun.

Water use seems to come  to base priorities for Tulare County. This from our story by AP staff writer Scott Smith gives you an idea of the struggle playing out: "Farming in Tulare County brought in $8.1 billion in 2014, more than any other county in the nation, according to its agricultural commissioner. Yet 1,252 of its household wells today are dry — more than all other California counties combined." Hola todos this is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an Instagram takeover this week from my photo essay on California's drought and its effects on a tiny Central Valley community known as Okieville. 
In this image, Elias Trejo squirts himself with a water balloon while running around in his yard with his sister.  Despite pleas from his family to stop wasting water, Elias couldn't resist, as temperatures in dusty Okieville hovered in the high nineties. The family had stopped using water for irrigating any kind of lawn or ground cover. Two large planters flanking their front door sat empty. Only an occasional trickle went to keep the few trees alive. So when Elias decided to sneak a little water for a water balloon fight with his sister, it was hard to blame him. 
The strange thing about the Central Valley is, despite all the dry wells and talk of drought, you actually see water all over the place. Water gushes out of irrigation pipes on the large farms that circle Okieville. It sits in rows of corn that stand at least eight feet tall. And it comes from the same place, underground, pumped up by wells. Just deeper. Deep wells are expensive to drill, and most of the families of field workers can't come up with the thousands of dollars it takes to drill down to where water still exists. So their shallow wells run dry.

This is my fourth day, following after @jacquelynmartin and her lovely essay on the Secret Service. It's been a blast so far! In this image, Billy Dunlap, 21, hauls in boxes of bottled water as his son, Brandon, 3, walks alongside at their home in the community of Okieville. Four generations of Dunlaps share the house, and their family is one of the few remaining from the Okieville camp set up in the 1940s. Little has changed in all those years, until the family's 170-foot well ran dry in February. The Dunlaps were very happy to see the truck carrying bottled water pull up to their home while we were there. A small mistake in a form during the previous month meant no bottled water deliveries for all of June for them.

Hola todos this is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an Instagram takeover this week from my photo essay on California's drought. This is my fourth day, following after @jacquelynmartin and her lovely essay on the Secret Service. It's been a blast so far! If you have any questions for me, please feel free to comment and I will get back to you. Thanks!

In this picture, Yaritza Pizano, 4, left, prays alongside her grandmother, Maria Marquez, in their home in the community of Okieville, in California's Central Valley.  As Yaritza's family began to run out of available water in 2014, she began to pray for it during her nightly prayer. “God, give us water so we don’t have to move,” the 4-year-old says, pressing her palms together. 
Before San Diego, I was based in Latin America for many years. I've photographed many scenes of prayer, but never prayer for water. Yaritza, so little, can already pick up on the deep concerns of the family. But she is in good hands with her grandmother, Maria. You can feel Maria's tenacity, strength, in that house, as if somehow things are going to be okay in the end. 
In this essay, and in the story by staff writer Scott Smith, we really wanted to feel what it was like for the people in the epicenter of California's drought. Pictures showing land erosion on hillsides and crops can be powerful too, but this time we wanted to let drought's victims speak. 
Look for more images from my photo essay at apimages.com or at http://bit.ly/1UgSEqk or here @ap.images during this week.

This is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an #instagram #takeover of a tiny, drought-stricken community called Okieville, in California’s Central Valley. 
In this picture, Tree Dunlap holds an image of her Oklahoma ancestors as she stands near the house she shares with four generations of her family. The Dunlaps have lived in Okieville since it was an Okieville - the name given to the camps of people who fled the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. Chased out of Oklahoma by drought, they have landed in another. The Dunlaps are one of the last remaining families from the Dust Bowl era in Okieville, and I got the sense they weren't planning on going anywhere anytime soon. To me, the Dunlaps seemed to be most about tradition, family. But with a well that pumps up nothing but sand, their future is less than clear.

This is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an #instagram #takeover of drought in California's Central Valley.

In this picture, rancher Steve Drumright looks toward his cattle, grazing on a barren hillside in Tulare County. His herd is forced to search the bald Tulare County hills for dwindling vegetation as California endures a fourth year of drought. In the moment I shot this picture, Steve is frustrated as he looks off towards his cattle. The blue water tank had leaked, spilling precious water. It meant less water for the animals as the temperatures reached into the high nineties on that July day.

This is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an #instagram #takeover from a tiny, drought-stricken community called Okieville, in California’s Central Valley. It’s so dry in these parts, its nickname has become all too ironic: Okieville was the name given to the camps of people who fled the Dust Bowl.

In this picture, Maria Marquez holds her 3-year-old granddaughter, Serenity Palomera, after a bath. When their family well ran out of water, Marquez sent Serenity and her cousin Yaritza to stay with other relatives. After three months, officials installed a large water tank in front of their home that gets filled every Monday, allowing the family to flush and bathe - and allowing Yaritza and Serenity to move back.

Bath time looked like it was a highlight for Serenity and her cousin Yaritza. Maria made the most of the water, scooping up the ankle-deep water with a tiny pink bucket to douse the girls. Their favorite part: turning the shallow water into a slide, flopping in from the back edge of the tub.

This is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an #instagram #takeover from a tiny, drought-stricken community called Okieville, in California’s Central Valley. It’s so dry in these parts, its nickname has become all too ironic: Okieville was the name given to the camps of people who fled the Dust Bowl.

In this image, Gilbert Arredondo had just informed his tenant that the well connecting both families had gone dry. He didn't need to tell him, though. His tenant is Lozano, in my earlier post, who got to watch the last few drops all on his own. Pipes and hoses snake through this community, as neighbors help neighbors, patching the few remaining working wells to the houses without. The whole thing feels so frail. Everybody knows this broken system won't save them for long. 
Look for more images from my photo essay at apimages.com or here @ap.images during this next week. And congrats to @jacquelynmartin for her wonderful work and takeover on the Secret Service, loved it!

This is AP staff photog @gregorybull, posting an #instagram #takeover from a tiny, drought-stricken community called Okieville, in California’s Central Valley. It’s so dry in these parts, its nickname has become all too ironic: Okieville was the name given to the camps of people who fled the Dust Bowl.

For most of us in California, including my own family in San Diego, the drought is a cause we all have united around because we’ve been told it’s happening. At my house, we ripped out our grass and put in agaves. We cut down watering. But it all seemed so insignificant once I visited Okieville.  It’s hard to capture in pictures the real sense of such a rapid decline. Wells went dry beneath our feet. In this picture, Tino Lozano watches as the last drop plops out of his hose and hits the bucket. There was this kind of pause, as he seemed to be forcing himself to adjust to his life’s new reality. Then he said, "“There it goes. That was all. That’s how we do it in Okieville now.” Look for more from my photo essay at apimages.com and here at @ap.images during this week

Btw congrats to @jacquelynmartin for her wonderful work and takeover on the Secret Service, loved it!

The AP always has a photographer in the "pool" of traveling press corps who cover President Obama and the White House and are allowed inside the bubble to photograph President Obama at his public events and his travels across the country. It's important for me as a photographer to find personal projects to work on, and it was during this coverage that I became fascinated by the Secret Service and its visual alphabet of dark suits, sunglasses, and earpieces. Within my presidential coverage I began to look for moments happening among the Secret Service agents to form this essay. The agency has its own intricate choreography, as the agents stay vigilant against all threats. These photos are a look at the Secret Service as seen from inside the bubble. If you enjoy political photography don't miss the work of my colleagues @pablomartinezmonsivais @evanvucci @andyharnik Signing off from the presidential motorcade, thanks and as we say in the business, see you in the wide shots!

Hello @ap.images followers! This is @jacquelynmartin a staff photojournalist with the AP based in Washington, DC. It’s my privilege to host this @instagram #takeover of the #AP feed for this week with my photo essay looking at the U.S. Secret Service. As you might expect, in Washington we cover a lot of politics. In my time covering the White House the U.S. Secret Service and its visual alphabet of dark suits, sunglasses, and earpieces has fascinated me. The agency has its own intricate choreography, as the agents stay vigilant against all threats. The agents have a dangerous and high pressure job to do as the U.S. Secret Service is the agency charged with protecting the life of the President of United States. The agency also celebrated its 150th birthday this past July. These photos are a look at the Secret Service as seen from inside the bubble.

In this photo a Secret Service Agent is seen through tinted and patterned glass as he stands in front of the door to a room where President Barack Obama was meeting with leading CEOs to discuss ways to promote the economy, at the Business Roundtable Headquarters in Washington. #APPhoto by @jacquelynmartin to see more of my work please visit blog.apimages.com

Ruby Sales, founder and director of The SpiritHouse Project, an Atlanta-based nonprofit dealing with discrimination, sits for a photo in Atlanta. Fifty years after Jonathan Daniels was shot dead by an ardent segregationist in Alabama, the people who stood with him then lament today's killings of blacks by police and the racially motivated slaying of nine black worshippers as stark reminders of the country's persistent racial divide. "Race relations today in the United States are an extension of that time period," Sales said. #APPhoto by @apdavidgoldman

A koala sleeps in its new enclosure at the Singapore Zoo, Wednesday, May 20, 2015, in Singapore. Four koalas originating from Brisbane's Lone Pine Koala Sanctuary, will stay at the Singapore Zoo until January 2016 before returning to Australia. The Singapore Zoo is also known for its efforts in promoting and educating the public about the importance of wildlife conservation through its educational programs and through the breeding of endangered species in captivity. Koalas are considered 'vulnerable' and are threatened by habitat loss and encroachment. #AP Photo by @w0ngmayee

Filipino boxer Meljun Penapin poses with his worn-out boxing gloves inside a boxing gym in suburban Paranaque, south of Manila, Philippines. Manny Pacquiao's rise from crushing poverty to global fame and fortune has inspired a whole generation of Filipino fighters, who look up to his legend as their dream and boxing as a ticket out of harsh lives and uncertainties. Penapin, 19, said, “I want to be a champion like Pacquiao... I was thinking that maybe I will be lucky. With such a hard life, maybe I will find my way of living here.” #APPhoto by @aaronfavila
